channel.title: Posts on TRxiv2
channel.description: Recent content in Posts on TRxiv2

item.title: anesthesia
item.description: Comparison of ChatGPT vs. Bard to Anesthesia-related Queries Authors: Patnaik, S. S.; Hoffmann, U. Score: 2.5, Published: 2023-06-30 DOI: 10.1101/2023.06.29.23292057 We investigated the ability of large language models (LLMs) to answer anesthesia related queries prior to surgery from a patient's point of view. In the study, we introduced textual data evaluation metrics, investigated ''hallucinations'' phenomenon, and evaluated feasibility of using LLMs at the patient-clinician interface. ChatGPT was found to be lengthier, intellectual, and effective in its response as compared to Bard.

item.title: animal behavior and cognition
item.description: A model-based hypothesis framework to define and estimate the diel niche via the 'Diel.Niche' R package Authors: Gerber, B. D.; Devarajan, K.; Farris, Z. J.; Fidino, M. Score: 31.8, Published: 2023-06-24 DOI: 10.1101/2023.06.21.545898 O_LIHow animals use the diel period (24-hour light-dark cycle) is of fundamental importance to understand their niche. While ecological and evolutionary literature abound with discussion of diel phenotypes (e.g., diurnal, nocturnal, crepuscular, cathemeral), they lack clear and explicit quantitative definitions.

item.title: biochemistry
item.description: Intrinsically Disordered Regions Promote Protein Refoldability and Facilitate Retrieval from Biomolecular Condensates Authors: To, P.; Bhagwat, A. M.; Tarbox, H. E.; Ecer, A.; Wendorff, H.; Jamieson, Z.; Trcek, T.; Fried, S. D. Score: 129.8, Published: 2023-06-25 DOI: 10.1101/2023.06.25.546465 Many eukaryotic proteins contain intrinsically disordered regions (IDRs) that intersperse globular folded domains, in contrast with bacterial proteins which are typically highly globular1, 2. Recent years have seen great progress in identifying biological functions associated with these elusive protein sequence: in specific cases, they mediate liquid liquid phase separation3, perform molecular recognition4, or act as sensors to changes in the environment5.

item.title: bioengineering
item.description: Direct 3D-bioprinting of hiPSC-derived cardiomyocytes to generate functional cardiac tissues Authors: Esser, T. U.; Anspach, A.; Muenzebrock, K. A.; Kah, D.; Schruefer, S.; Schenk, J.; Heinze, K. G.; Schubert, D. W.; Fabry, B.; Engel, F. B. Score: 44.8, Published: 2023-06-12 DOI: 10.1101/2023.06.12.544557 3D-bioprinting is a promising technology to produce human tissues as drug screening tool or for organ repair. However, direct printing of living cells has proven difficult. Here, we present a method to directly 3D-bioprint human induced pluripotent stem cell (hiPSC)-derived cardiomyocytes embedded in a collagen-hyaluronic acid ink generating centimeter-sized functional ring- and ventricle-shaped cardiac tissues in an accurate and reproducible manner.

item.title: bioinformatics
item.description: DrugGPT: A GPT-based Strategy for Designing Potential Ligands Targeting Specific Proteins Authors: Li, Y.; Gao, C.; Song, X.; Wang, X.; Xu, Y.; Han, S. Score: 29.8, Published: 2023-06-30 DOI: 10.1101/2023.06.29.543848 DrugGPT presents a ligand design strategy based on the autoregressive model, GPT, focusing on chemical space exploration and the discovery of ligands for specific proteins. Deep learning language models have shown significant potential in various domains including protein design and biomedical text analysis, providing strong support for the proposition of DrugGPT.

item.title: biophysics
item.description: Fiber alignment in 3D collagen networks as a biophysical marker for cell contractility Authors: Boehringer, D.; Bauer, A.; Moravec, I.; Bischof, L.; Kah, D.; Mark, C.; Grundy, T. J.; Goerlach, E.; O'Neill, G. M.; Budday, S.; Strissel, P.; Strick, R.; Malandrino, A.; Gerum, R.; Mak, M.; Rausch, M.; Fabry, B. Score: 30.1, Published: 2023-06-29 DOI: 10.1101/2023.06.28.546896 Cells cultured in 3D fibrous biopolymer matrices exert traction forces on their environment that induce deformations and remodeling of the fiber network.

item.description: Deep intravital brain tumor imaging enabled by tailored three-photon microscopy and analysis Authors: Schubert, M. C.; Soyka, S. J.; Tamimi, A.; Maus, E.; Denninger, R.; Wissmann, N.; Reyhan, E.; Tetzlaff, S. K.; Beretta, C.; Drumm, M.; Schroers, J.; Steffens, A.; Walshon, J.; McCortney, K.; Heiland, S.; Golebiewska, A.; Kurz, F. T.; Wick, W.; Winkler, F.; Kreshuk, A.; Kuner, T.; Horbinski, C.; Prevedel, R.; Venkataramani, V. Score: 48.2, Published: 2023-06-21 DOI: 10.

item.title: cardiovascular medicine
item.description: Integrative metabolomics differentiate coronary artery disease, peripheral artery disease, and venous thromboembolism risks Authors: Lee, J.; Gilliland, T.; Koyama, S.; Nakao, T.; Dron, J.; Lannery, K.; Wong, M.; Peloso, G. M.; Hornsby, W.; Natarajan, P. Score: 9.0, Published: 2023-06-27 DOI: 10.1101/2023.06.21.23291103 RationaleArterial and venous cardiovascular conditions, such as coronary artery disease (CAD), peripheral artery disease (PAD), and venous thromboembolism (VTE), are genetically correlated. Interrogating distinct and overlapping mechanisms may shed new light on disease mechanisms.

item.title: cell biology
item.description: Self-extinguishing relay waves enable homeostaticcontrol of human neutrophil swarming Authors: Strickland, J.; Pan, D.; Godfrey, C.; Kim, J. S.; Hopke, A.; Degrange, M.; Villavicencio, B.; Mansour, M. K.; Zerbe, C. S.; Irimia, D.; Amir, A.; Weiner, O. D. Score: 313.3, Published: 2023-06-28 DOI: 10.1101/2023.06.27.546744 Neutrophils exhibit self-amplified swarming to sites of injury and infection. How swarming is controlled to ensure the proper level of neutrophil recruitment is unknown. Using an ex vivo model of infection, we find that human neutrophils use active relay to generate multiple pulsatile waves of swarming signals.

item.title: developmental biology
item.description: Transgene-Free Ex Utero Derivation of A Human Post-Implantation Embryo Model Solely from Genetically Unmodified Naive PSCs Authors: Oldak, B.; Wildschutz, E.; Bondarenko, V.; Aguilera-Castrejon, A.; Zhao, C.; Tarazi, S.; Comar, M.-Y.; Ashouokhi, S.; Lokshtanov, D.; Roncato, F.; Viukov, S.; Ariel, E.; Rose, M.; Livnat, N.; Shani, T.; Joubran, C.; Cohen, R.; Addadi, Y.; Kedmi, M.; Keren-Shaul, H.; Petropoulos, S.; Lanner, F.; Novershtern, N.; Hanna, J. H. Score: 1225.2, Published: 2023-06-15 DOI: 10.

item.title: ecology
item.description: GIFT an R package to access the Global Inventory of Floras and Traits Authors: Denelle, P.; Weigelt, P.; Kreft, H. Score: 168.0, Published: 2023-06-28 DOI: 10.1101/2023.06.27.546704 1. Advancing knowledge of biodiversity requires open-access global databases and workflows. This appears particularly crucial for plants, as ongoing changes pose major threats to this central group of organisms. Having large-scale information on plant distributions, functional traits and evolutionary history will enable the scientific community to improve its understanding of the patterns and drivers of plant diversity on a global scale.

item.title: emergency medicine
item.description: Restrictions on top speed and nighttime usage substantially decrease the incidence of electric scooter injuries Authors: Pakarinen, O.; Kobylin, A.; Harjola, V.-P.; Castren, M.; Vasara, H. Score: 31.8, Published: 2023-06-27 DOI: 10.1101/2023.06.20.23291641 ObjectiveTo investigate the effectiveness of restrictions on top speed and nighttime usage on the incidence of e-scooter-related injuries. DesignA retrospective comparative study. We compared shared e-scooter injuries from two periods: Unrestricted period (1.1-31.8.2021), and Restricted period (1.1.-31.8.2022). SettingGeneral population of Helsinki, Finland.

item.title: endocrinology
item.description: Brain Dopamine Receptor System is Not Altered in Obesity: Bayesian and Frequentist Meta-Analyses Authors: Pak, K.; Nummenmaa, L. Score: 8.5, Published: 2023-06-25 DOI: 10.1101/2023.06.22.23291735 BackgroundFeeding induces dopamine release in the striatum, and a dysfunction of the dopaminergic reward system can lead to overeating, and obesity. Studies have reported inconsistent findings of dopamine receptor (DR) positron emission tomography (PET) scans in obesity. Here we investigated the association between DR availability and overweight/obesity using Bayesian and frequentist meta-analysis.

item.title: epidemiology
item.description: Design and Analysis Heterogeneity in Observational Studies of COVID-19 Booster Effectiveness: A Review and Case Study Authors: Meah, S.; Shi, X.; Fritsche, L. G.; Salvatore, M.; Wagner, A.; Martin, E. T.; Mukherjee, B. Score: 61.1, Published: 2023-06-28 DOI: 10.1101/2023.06.22.23291692 BackgroundObservational vaccine effectiveness (VE) studies based on real-world data are a crucial supplement to initial randomized clinical trials of Coronavirus Disease 2019 (COVID-19) vaccines. However, there exists substantial heterogeneity in study designs and statistical methods for estimating VE.

item.title: gastroenterology
item.description: Comprehensive profiling of the human intestinal DNA virome and prediction of disease-associated bacterial hosts in severe Myalgic Encephalomyelitis/Chronic Fatigue Syndrome (ME/CFS) Authors: Hsieh, S.-Y.; Savva, G. M.; Telatin, A.; Tiwari, S. K.; Tariq, M. A.; Newberry, F.; Seton, K. A.; Booth, C.; Bansal, A. S.; Wileman, T.; Andriaenssens, E.; Carding, S. R. Score: 12.0, Published: 2023-06-29 DOI: 10.1101/2023.06.29.23291738 Myalgic encephalomyelitis/chronic fatigue syndrome (ME/CFS) is a disabling disorder of unknown etiology with severely affected patients being house- and/or bedbound.

A.; Guare, L.; Ayakulangara Panickan, V.; Garcon, H.; Linares, F.; Costa, L.; Goethert, I.; Tipton, R.; Honerlaw, J.; Davies, L.; Whitbourne, S.; Cohen, J.; Posner, D. C.; Sangar, R.; Murray, M.; Wang, X.; Dochtermann, D. R.; Devineni, P.

item.title: genetics
item.description: Genetic similarity between relatives provides evidence on the presence and history of assortative mating Authors: Sunde, H. F.; Eftedal, N. H.; Cheesman, R.; Corfield, E. C.; Kleppesto, T. H.; Seierstad, A. C.; Ystrom, E.; Eilertsen, E. M.; Torvik, F. A. Score: 31.8, Published: 2023-06-29 DOI: 10.1101/2023.06.27.546663 Assortative mating - the non-random mating of individuals with similar traits - is known to increase trait-specific genetic variance and genetic similarity between relatives.

item.title: genomics
item.description: Sequence basis of transcription initiation in human genome Authors: Dudnyk, K.; Shi, C.; Zhou, J. Score: 66.3, Published: 2023-06-29 DOI: 10.1101/2023.06.27.546584 Transcription initiation is an essential process for ensuring proper function of any gene, however, a unified understanding of sequence patterns and rules that determine transcription initiation sites in human genome remains elusive. By explaining transcription initiation at basepair resolution from sequence with a deep learning-inspired explainable modeling approach, here we show that simple rules can explain the vast majority of human promoters.

item.title: health informatics
item.description: Machine learning in medicine using JavaScript: building web apps using TensorFlow.js for interpreting biomedical datasets Authors: Pires, J. G. Score: 3.2, Published: 2023-06-29 DOI: 10.1101/2023.06.21.23291717 IntroductionContributions to medicine may come from different areas; and most areas are full of researchers wanting to support. Physists may help with theory, such as for nuclear medicine. Engineers with machineries, such as dialysis machine. Mathematicians with models, such as pharmacokinetics. And computer scientists with codes such as bioinformatics.

item.title: health policy
item.description: The physical and mental health benefits of touch interventions: A comparative systematic review and multivariate meta-analysis Authors: Packheiser, J.; Hartmann, H.; Fredriksen, K.; Gazzola, V.; Keysers, C.; Michon, F. Score: 6.5, Published: 2023-06-20 DOI: 10.1101/2023.06.20.23291651 IntroductionReceiving touch is of critical importance for human well-being. A large number of studies have shown that touch promotes mental and physical health. However, effect sizes differ considerably across studies and potential moderators of touch interventions remain unknown to this day.

item.title: immunology
item.description: Paridiprubart inhibits TLR4-dependant NF-ÎºB activation by multiple pathogens Authors: Malty, R.; Hilbe, R.; Ahn, S.; Kesselman, L.; Lam, J.; Kasawara, K.; Costa, L.; Rajakulendran, N.; Gordon, B.; Brooks, M.; Mubareka, S.; Tancevski, I.; Gray-Owen, S. D. Score: 38.0, Published: 2023-06-27 DOI: 10.1101/2023.06.27.545921 Respiratory pathogens such as SARS-CoV-2 and influenza can activate an exaggerated inflammatory response (cytokine storm) in the lungs that may result in acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS), hospitalization, and death.

item.description: Increased circulating fibronectin, depletion of natural IgM and heightened EBV, HSV-1 reactivation in ME/CFS and long COVID Authors: Liu, Z.; Hollmann, C.; Kalanidhi, S.; Grothey, A.; Keating, S.; Mena-Palomo, I.; Lamer, S.; Schlosser, A.; Kaiping, A.; Scheller, C.; Sotzny, F.; Horn, A.; Nuernberger, C.; Cejka, V.; Afshar, B.; Bahmer, T.; Schreiber, S.; Janne Vehreschild, J.; Milljukov, O.; Schaefer, C.; Kretzler, L.; Keil, T.; Reese, J.-P.; Eichner, F. item.title: microbiology
item.description: Amazing structural diversity of giant virus-like particles in forest soil Authors: Fischer, M. G.; Mersdorf, U.; Blanchard, J. L. Score: 96.8, Published: 2023-06-30 DOI: 10.1101/2023.06.30.546935 Large DNA viruses of the phylum Nucleocytoviricota infect diverse eukaryotic hosts from protists to humans, with profound consequences for aquatic and terrestrial ecosystems. While nucleocytoviruses are known to be highly diverse in metagenomes, knowledge of their capsid structures is restricted to a few characterized representatives.

item.title: molecular biology
item.description: Programmable RNA-guided endonucleases are widespread in eukaryotes and their viruses Authors: Jiang, K.; Lim, J.; Sgrizzi, S.; Trinh, M.; Kayabolen, A.; Yutin, N.; Koonin, E. V.; Abudayyeh, O. O.; Gootenberg, J. S. Score: 241.2, Published: 2023-06-14 DOI: 10.1101/2023.06.13.544871 TnpB proteins are RNA-guided nucleases that are broadly associated with IS200/605 family transposons in prokaryotes. TnpB homologs, named Fanzors, have been detected in genomes of some eukaryotes and large viruses, but their activity and functions in eukaryotes remain unknown.

item.title: nephrology
item.description: Estimating the population-level kidney benefits of improved uptake of SGLT2 inhibitors in patients with chronic kidney disease in Australian primary care Authors: Neuen, B. L.; Jun, M.; Wick, J.; Kotwal, S.; Badve, S. V.; Jardine, M. J.; Gallagher, M.; Chalmers, J.; Nallaiah, K.; Perkovic, V.; Peiris, D.; Rodgers, A.; Woodward, M.; Ronksley, P. Score: 7.3, Published: 2023-06-28 DOI: 10.1101/2023.06.26.23291881 BackgroundAlthough sodium glucose co-transporter 2 (SGLT2) inhibitors reduce the risk of kidney failure and death in patients with chronic kidney disease (CKD), they are underused in routine clinical practice.

item.title: neurology
item.description: Vagus nerve inflammation contributes to dysautonomia in COVID-19 Authors: Woo, M. S.; Shafiq, M.; Fitzek, A.; Dottermusch, M.; Altmeppen, H.; Mohammadi, B.; Mayer, C.; Bal, L. C.; Raich, L.; Matschke, J.; Krasemann, S.; Pfefferle, S.; Brehm, T. T. S.; Luetgehetmann, M.; Schaedler, J.; Addo, M. M.; Schulze Zur Wiesch, J.; Ondruschka, B.; Friese, M. A.; Glatzel, M. Score: 98.7, Published: 2023-06-20 DOI: 10.1101/2023.06.14.23291320 Dysautonomia has substantially impacted acute COVID-19 severity as well as symptom burden after recovery from COVID-19 (long COVID), yet the underlying causes remain unknown.

item.title: nutrition
item.description: A prebiotic diet changes neural correlates of food decision- making in overweight adults: a randomized controlled within-subject cross-over trial Authors: Medawar, E.; Beyer, F.; Thieleking, R.; Haange, S.-B.; Rolle-Kampczyk, U.; Reinicke, M.; Chakaroun, R.; von Bergen, M.; Stumvoll, M.; Villringer, A.; Witte, V. Score: 13.3, Published: 2023-06-03 DOI: 10.1101/2023.05.30.23290707 ObjectiveAnimal studies suggest that prebiotic, plant-derived nutrients could improve homeostatic and hedonic brain functions through improvements in microbiome-gut-brain communication. However, little is known if these results are applicable to humans.

item.title: oncology
item.description: Strength of Statistical Evidence for the Efficacy of Cancer Drugs: A Bayesian Re-Analysis of Trials Supporting FDA Approval. Authors: Pittelkow, M.-M.; Linde, M.; de Vries, Y. A.; Hemkens, L. G.; Schmitt, A. M.; Meijer, R. R.; van Ravenzwaaij, D. Score: 4.7, Published: 2023-06-30 DOI: 10.1101/2023.06.30.23292074 Objective: To quantify the strength of statistical evidence of randomised controlled trials (RCTs) for novel cancer drugs approved by the Food and Drug Administration (FDA) in the last two decades.

item.title: paleontology
item.description: Evidence for deliberate burial of the dead by Homo naledi Authors: Berger, L. R.; Makhubela, T.; Molopyane, K.; Kruger, A.; Randolph-Quinney, P.; Elliott, M.; Peixotto, B.; Fuentes, A.; Tafforeau, P.; Beyrand, V.; Dollman, K.; Jinnah, Z.; Brewer Gillham, A.; Broad, K.; Brophy, J.; Chinamatira, G.; Dirks, P.; Feuerriegel, E.; Gurtov, A.; Hlophe, N.; Hunter, L.; Hunte, R.; Jakata, K.; Jaskolski, C.; Morris, H.; Pryor, E.; Ramaphela, M.; Roberts, E.; Smilg, J.

item.title: pathology
item.description: Extended correlation functions for spatial analysis of multiplex imaging data Authors: Bull, J. A.; Mulholland, E. J.; Leedham, S. J.; Byrne, H. M. Score: 2.0, Published: 2023-06-23 DOI: 10.1101/2023.06.20.545678 Imaging platforms for generating highly multiplexed histological images are being continually developed and improved. Significant improvements have also been made in the accuracy of methods for automated cell segmentation and classification. However, less attention has focussed on the quantification and analysis of the resulting point clouds which describe the spatial coordinates of individual cells.

item.title: pediatrics
item.description: Early-life seizures and epileptic spasms in STXBP1-related disorders Authors: Thalwitzer, K.; Xian, J.; deCampo, D.; Parthasarathy, S.; Magielski, J.; Sullivan, K. R.; Goss, J.; Son Rigby, C.; Boland, M.; Prosser, B.; Ruggiero, S. M.; Syrbe, S.; Helbig, I. Score: 2.6, Published: 2023-06-28 DOI: 10.1101/2023.06.26.23291892 Background and ObjectivesIndividuals with disease-causing variants in STXBP1 frequently have epilepsy onset in the first year of life with a variety of seizure types, including epileptic spasms.

item.title: pharmacology and therapeutics
item.description: Low Dose Naltrexone use for the management of post acute sequelae of COVID 19 Authors: Bonilla, H.; Tian, L.; Marconi, V.; Shafer, R. W.; Mccomsey, G.; Miglis, M. G.; Yang, P. C.; Geng, L. N. Score: 23.6, Published: 2023-06-12 DOI: 10.1101/2023.06.08.23291102 Post-Acute Sequelae of SARS-CoV-2 (PASC), also known as Long COVID, is globally estimated to have affected up to 40-50% of individuals who were infected with SARS-CoV-2. The causes of PASC are being investigated, and there are no established therapies.

item.title: pharmacology and toxicology
item.description: Characterization of cannabinoid plasma concentration, maternal health, and cytokine levels in a rat model of prenatal Cannabis smoke exposure Authors: Black, T.; Baccetto, S. L.; Barnard, I. L.; Finch, E.; McElroy, D. L.; Austin-Scott, F. V.; Greba, Q.; Michel, D.; Zagzoog, A.; Howland, J. G.; Laprairie, R. B. Score: 9.0, Published: 2023-06-21 DOI: 10.1101/2023.06.16.545309 Cannabis sativa has gained popularity as a "natural substance", leading many to falsely assume that it is not harmful.

C.; Breeze, E.; Ubrik, R.; Robitzsch, C.; Agyin-Birikorang, A.; Mattingly, M. L.; Michel, J. M.; Kontos, N. J.; Fruge, A. D.; Wilborn, C. M.; Weimar, W. H.; Bashir, A.; Beyers, R. item.title: plant biology
item.description: The receptor-like kinase BIR1 inhibits elicitor-induced plasmodesmata callose deposition and PTI gene expression and requires EDS1 and SOBIR1 to cause dose-dependent cell-death in Arabidopsis Authors: GUZMAN-BENITO, I.; ROBINSON, C.; HUA, C.; SEDE, A. R.; ELVIRA-GONZALEZ, L.; PUNZON, I.; HEINLEIN, M.; NURNBERGER, T.; LLAVE, C. Score: 16.6, Published: 2023-06-23 DOI: 10.1101/2023.06.23.546234 O_LIThe receptor-like kinase BIR1 functions as a negative regulator of cell death and defense in Arabidopsis. Previous studies showed that BIR1 expression is up-regulated during infections with microbes and viruses.

item.title: psychiatry and clinical psychology
item.description: Mapping neurodevelopmental diversity in executive function Authors: Mareva, S.; The CALM Team, ; Holmes, J. Score: 22.2, Published: 2023-06-16 DOI: 10.1101/2023.06.15.23291392 Executive functions can be conceptualised as either a set of higher-order cognitive skills that enable us to engage in flexible thinking and regulate our thoughts and behaviours, or as the ability to integrate knowledge, beliefs, and values when applying cognitive control in everyday situations. These two perspectives map onto the ways in which executive function is measured in childhood - using either structured laboratory tasks or ratings of everyday behaviours.

item.title: public and global health
item.description: mRNA-1273 vaccine effectiveness against symptomatic SARS-CoV-2 infection and COVID-19-related hospitalization in children aged 6 months to 5 years Authors: Aglipay, M.; Maguire, J. L.; Swayze, S.; Tuite, A.; Mamdani, M.; Keown-Stoneman, C.; Birken, C. S.; Kwong, J. C. Score: 67.8, Published: 2023-06-28 DOI: 10.1101/2023.06.27.23291933 ImportanceData on mRNA-1273 (Moderna) vaccine effectiveness in children aged 6 months to 5 years are limited. ObjectiveTo assess mRNA-1273 vaccine effectiveness against symptomatic SARS-CoV-2 infection and COVID-19-related hospitalization among children aged 6 months to 5 years.

item.title: rehabilitation medicine and physical therapy
item.description: Lower Dynamic Cerebral Autoregulation following Acute Bout of Low-Volume High-Intensity Interval Exercise in Chronic Stroke Compared to Healthy Adults Authors: Whitaker, A. A.; Aaron, S. E.; Chertoff, M.; Brassard, P.; Buchanan, J.; Nguyen, K.; Vidoni, E.; Waghmare, S.; Eickmeyer, S.; Billinger, S. Score: 5.6, Published: 2023-06-20 DOI: 10.1101/2023.06.13.23291289 Fluctuating blood pressure during high-intensity interval exercise (HIIT) may challenge dynamic cerebral autoregulation (dCA), specifically post-stroke after an injury to the cerebrovasculature.

item.title: scientific communication and education
item.description: Insights on Poster Preparation Practices in Life Sciences Authors: Jambor, H. Score: 18.2, Published: 2023-06-06 DOI: 10.1101/2020.10.08.331413 Posters are intended to spark scientific dialogue and omnipresent at biological conferences. Guides and how-to articles help life scientists in preparing informative visualizations in poster format. However, those posters shown at conferences are at present often overloaded with data and text and are poorly designed, which in sum hinder, rather than spark communication.

item.title: synthetic biology
item.description: Truly tiny acoustic biomolecules for ultrasound imaging and therapy Authors: Ling, B.; Gungoren, B.; Yao, Y.; Dutka, P.; Smith, C. A. B.; Lee, J.; Swift, M. B.; Shapiro, M. G. Score: 15.2, Published: 2023-06-28 DOI: 10.1101/2023.06.27.546773 Nanotechnology offers significant advantages for medical imaging and therapy, including enhanced contrast and precision targeting. However, integrating these benefits into ultrasonography has been challenging due to the size and stability constraints of conventional bubble-based agents.

item.title: systems biology
item.description: Simultaneous Multi-Omics Analysis by Direct Infusion Mass Spectrometry (SMAD-MS) Authors: Jiang, Y.; Salladay-Perez, I.; Momenzadeh, A.; Covarrubias, A. J.; Meyer, J. G. Score: 22.3, Published: 2023-06-29 DOI: 10.1101/2023.06.26.546628 Combined multi-omics analysis of proteomics, polar metabolomics, and lipidomics requires separate liquid chromatography-mass spectrometry (LC-MS) platforms for each omics layer. This requirement for different platforms limits throughput and increases costs, preventing the application of mass spectrometry-based multi-omics to large scale drug discovery or clinical cohorts.

item.title: transplantation
item.description: Role of renal venous oxygen pressure for renal function monitoring after related living-donor kidney transplantation: cohort study Authors: Escarraman-Martinez, D.; Fernandez-Bravo, M.; Kammar-Garcia, A.; Guerrero-Gutierrez, M. A.; Meza-Comparan, H. D.; Mancilla-Galindo, J.; Sanchez-Diaz, J. S.; Cendejas-Rios, E.; Escorza-Molina, C. A.; Noriega-Salas, L.; Bernaldez-Gomez, G. Score: 3.2, Published: 2023-06-22 DOI: 10.1101/2023.06.15.23291421 IntroductionMonitoring of renal function after kidney transplantation (KT) is performed by measuring serum creatinine (SCr), urine volumes (UV), and glomerular filtration rate (GFR).

item.title: zoology
item.description: Physiological phenotypes differ among color morphs in introduced populations of the common wall lizard, Podarcis muralis Authors: Amer, A.; Spears, S.; Vaughn, P. L.; Colwell, C.; Livingston, E. H.; McQueen, W.; Schill, A.; Reichard, D.; Gangloff, E. J.; Brock, K. M. Score: 8.9, Published: 2023-06-21 DOI: 10.1101/2023.06.17.545449 Many species exhibit color polymorphisms which have distinct physiological and behavioral characteristics. However, the consistency of morph trait covariation patterns across species, time, and ecological contexts remains unclear.
